title: Greenland diving tour takes holidaymakers under spectacular icebergs
text:
View
comments
A British travel company has become one of the first in the world to take adventurous holidaymakers on organised dives under Greenland’s spectacular icebergs.
Daredevils who splash nearly £5,000 on the trip can swim beneath giant chunks of glacier ice and view them in a way they have rarely been seen before.
Each dive with Wiltshire-based Arctic Direct normally lasts up to 45 minutes, depending on the divers' comfort in the cold water.

The trip is ideal for those who don’t mind getting away from it all and are keen to explore unspoilt landscapes and icebergs they won’t see anywhere else.
Arctic Direct has started offering six-day tours of the remote island, with the cost covering flights, transfers, accommodation and diving.

There are plenty of opportunities to explore the blue waters surrounding the island, with groups of up to 12 doing eight to 10 dives, depending on the water and weather conditions.
Charlotte Marshall-Reynolds, managing director of Arctic Direct, said Greenland is much more remote than other Arctic dive sites because it's the least densely populated country on earth.
The trip is ideal for those who are keen to explore unspoilt landscapes and icebergs they won’t see anywhere else
She added: ‘There's some fantastic wildlife, the icebergs, unspoilt and unique landscapes.
‘The water there has excellent visibility, even at more than 50 metres [165ft], and the blues and whites of the icebergs are mesmerising.
‘The conditions are a dream for those interested in photography too.’
There are plenty of opportunities to explore the blue waters surrounding the island, with groups of up to 12 doing eight to 10 dives
In addition to incredible icebergs, divers can see coral walls, kelp forests, whale cemeteries and shipwrecks, and they may even swim with humpback, fin, sperm and blue whales.
Ms Marshall-Reynolds added: ‘Arctic diving is of interest to people who don't want to be diving with hundreds of other people. Those who would like to dive at sites which, in some cases, may never have been dived before.
‘The guide has to look for a suitable iceberg to dive. In the constantly changing scenery with icebergs it is important to ensure safety and make sure there is adequate space around the iceberg.’
